full_conversation: Therapist: How are you feeling after that imaginal exposure?

Client: I'm... I'm not sure. It's a lot to process. Going through that memory of the racial abuse I experienced at work... it brought up so many emotions. I felt angry, scared, and ashamed all at once. It's like I was right back there, you know?
Therapist: That's understandable. What stood out to you most?

Client: The feeling of powerlessness, I think. When my coworker made those racist comments and everyone just laughed... I wanted to stand up for myself, but I froze. I can still hear their laughter echoing in my head.
Therapist: How did reliving that moment affect you physically?

Client: My heart was racing, and I felt this tightness in my chest. My palms got sweaty, and I had this urge to run away, even though I knew I was safe here. It's frustrating that my body still reacts so strongly to a memory.
Therapist: That's a common response. How does this connect to your day-to-day life?

Client: I guess... I've been avoiding social situations at work. I'm always on edge, expecting someone to say something hurtful. It's exhausting, and it's definitely affecting my performance and relationships with colleagues.
Therapist: I see. What insights did you gain from this experience?
Client: Well, I realized that I'm still carrying a lot of pain from that incident. But also... I survived it. I'm here now, talking about it. Maybe I'm stronger than I give myself credit for.
Therapist: That's a powerful realization. How might you use this strength?
Client: I... I think I could start by speaking up more at work. Maybe set some boundaries. It's scary, but I don't want to feel powerless anymore.
Therapist: That's a great goal. How do you feel about continuing this work?

Client: It's tough, and sometimes I wonder if it's worth it. But then I think about how much this has been holding me back. I want to feel free, you know? To just be myself without all this fear and anger weighing me down. So yeah, I'm willing to keep going.
Therapist: Your commitment is admirable. What support do you need?
Client: I think... maybe some strategies for managing anxiety in the moment? And... I don't know, maybe some affirmations or something to remind myself of my worth when I'm feeling low?
Therapist: Those are excellent ideas. Shall we work on those next time?
Client: Yes, please. I'm nervous but also kind of excited. It feels good to be taking action, you know?
Therapist: That's a positive attitude. How will you care for yourself this week?
Client: I think I'll try that meditation app you recommended. And maybe reach out to my sister - she's always been supportive. Oh, and I promised myself a nice bubble bath after today's session.
Therapist: Sounds like a good plan. Any final thoughts before we wrap up?
Client: Just... thank you. For listening, for guiding me through this. It's not easy, but I feel like I'm finally moving forward instead of being stuck in the past.
Therapist: You're doing great work. See you next week?
Client: Definitely. See you then.
